g.title: Rectangle
g.desc: Simple Factory Delegate object creation to a separate class
g.text: Simple FactoryDelegate object creation to a separate class

g.title: Folded Corner.20
g.desc: The Simple Factory compliments the Single Responsibility prin...

g.text: The Simple Factory compliments the Single Responsibility principle by extracting (complex) object construction from client code. This ensures reusability, stability and readability of the code. All aspects are compared against an implementation where client constructs its dependencies internally. Reusability, delegation of object creation to a separate class allows other clients to re-use the same construction logic. In case the system requires to work with a different concrete Product it can be substituted in a single place (=Factory). In contrast, when a concrete object has multiple instantiations across the code base (duplication), substitution must done in multiple places. Stability, a change in construction code does not impact client code directly and vice versa. This minimizes the chance of breaking code unrelated to the change. Readability, because (complex) object construction logic is extracted from client code. This makes the client code more ‘focused’.

g.title: Folded Corner.40
g.desc: The Simple Factory violates the Open Closed Principle. A Simp...

g.text: The Simple Factory violates the Open Closed Principle. A Simple factory is often composed of a switch-case statement. This defeats the purpose of Open Closed, because we have to change the factory when we would like to introduce a new ‘kind’ of product.

g.title: Rectangle.59
g.desc: Delegate object creation to a separate class
g.text: Delegate object creation to a separate class

g.title: Rectangle.62
g.desc: The Abstract Factory is over done
g.text: The Abstract Factory is over done

g.title: Folded Corner.64
g.desc: The Simple Factory is not an official Design pattern. However...

g.text: The Simple Factory is not an official Design pattern. However, the term Factory is often mis-used, so it is worthwhile to clarify the different Factory forms. The Simple Factory is a simplified version of the Abstract Factory. It’s primary responsibility is to extract object construction from client code to share, clarify and have flexibility of change (to some extend). The Simple Factory prescribes object (=Product) creation via a conditional structure (e.g. switch/case, if-else). Clients dependent directly on the concrete Factory and requests the required dependency via a parameter (e.g. enum). The Products (=dependencies), produced by the Factory, are behind an interface. This allows clients to be more adaptive to change.

g.title: Folded Corner.68
g.desc: The Simple Factory prescribes delegation of object constructi...

g.text: The Simple Factory prescribes delegation of object construction to a separate class, just like the Abstract Factory. However, the Abstract Factory is more about creation of families of objects and Factory flexibility. The Abstraction Factory constraints products to be created as a group. This guarantees safety and clarifies design intent. The Simple Factory does not necessarily prescribe this constraining behavior. On top of that, the Abstract Factory, as the name indicates, is behind an Abstraction. This allows the Factory instance to be swapped with another concrete Factory without modification of the clients. This might be useful in case the Factory, a client works with, requires change during runtime. In contrast, the Simple Factory is concrete, resulting in less flexibility. In case the constraining nor the flexibility is required the Simple Factory is preferred. The Simple Factory ensures less indirections (no factory abstraction) allowing navigation and debugging ease.

g.title: Folded Corner.73
g.desc: The Simple Factory both entails the negative and positive sid...

g.text: The Simple Factory both entails the negative and positive side of the Single Responsibility Principle. Delegating object creation to a separate class introduces an additional form of indirection. This makes it harder to comprehend the dependency model of the client, because logic is more scattered.
